title: Can you still feel a limb that's gone? - Joshua W. Pate

multiple-choice.question: What is a common phenomenon experienced by people who have lost a limb?

options.label: A
options.text: They can no longer feel sensations in the missing limb.

options.label: B
options.text: They can feel the missing limb in complete lifelike detail.

options.label: C
options.text: They experience temporary numbness in the remaining limbs.

options.label: D
options.text: They have reduced sensitivity in the remaining limbs.

multiple-choice.question: What is the name of the model that represents the human body with proportions based on the size of each body part's representation in the cortex?
What happens to the representation of a body part in the cortex when it receives more sensory input?
What is a possible explanation for the feeling of body parts that are no longer there?

options.label: A
options.text: The brain's inability to process sensory information

options.label: B
options.text: The presence of phantom limb sensations

options.label: C
options.text: The cortical map still having representation of the missing body part

options.label: D
options.text: The loss of inhibitory control in the dorsal horn

multiple-choice.question: What is the purpose of mirror box therapy in treating phantom pain?

options.label: A
options.text: To reduce pain by stimulating the intact limb

options.label: B
options.text: To trick the brain into seeing the phantom limb

options.label: C
options.text: To increase cortical representation of the missing limb

options.label: D
options.text: To decrease sensory input from the remaining limbs

multiple-choice.question: What is a common experience reported by patients who use prosthetics?

options.label: A
options.text: They experience more pain when wearing prosthetics

options.label: B
options.text: They experience less pain when wearing prosthetics

options.label: C
options.text: They experience pain primarily when they remove their prosthetics at night

options.label: D
options.text: They experience no pain when wearing prosthetics

multiple-choice.question: What is the name of the part of the brain that processes sensory signals from the body?
What happens to the severed nerve endings at the site of an amputation?

options.label: C
options.text: They thicken and become more sensitive

multiple-choice.question: What is a potential benefit of further research into phantom limbs?

options.label: A
options.text: It may lead to the development of more advanced prosthetics

options.label: B
options.text: It may provide insight into the work our brains do every day to build the world as we perceive it

options.label: C
options.text: It may lead to the discovery of a cure for phantom pain

options.label: D
options.text: It may result in a better understanding of the neural pathways involved in sensory perception

multiple-choice.question: What is a characteristic of the phantom limbs experienced by people who have undergone an amputation?

options.label: C
options.text: They are experienced by only a few people

options.label: D
options.text: They are experienced by everyone who undergoes an amputation

title: Everything you need to know to read "The Canterbury Tales" - Iseult Gillespie

multiple-choice.question: Who is the author of "The Canterbury Tales"?

What is the social system that divided Medieval society into different classes?
How many stories are included in "The Canterbury Tales"?
What is the name of the character who proposes a competition to tell the best tale?
What is the language in which "The Canterbury Tales" is written?
What is the significance of the varied dialects, genres, and literary tropes in "The Canterbury Tales"?

options.label: A
options.text: They make the work a vivid record of Medieval history

options.label: B
options.text: They make the work a vivid record of the different ways Medieval audiences entertained themselves

options.label: C
options.text: They make the work a commentary on modern society

options.label: D
options.text: They make the work a critique of the feudal system

multiple-choice.question: Why is it possible that Chaucer never finished "The Canterbury Tales"?

options.label: A
options.text: He was dissatisfied with the work

options.label: B
options.text: He was too busy with other projects

options.label: C
options.text: He was so caught up in his creations that he delayed picking a winner

options.label: D
options.text: He lost interest in the project

title: The "End Of History" Illusion - Bence Nanay

multiple-choice.question: What is the main idea behind the concept of "The End of History Illusion"?

options.label: A
options.text: That people tend to overestimate their ability to predict future change

options.label: B
options.text: That people tend to underestimate their ability to predict future change

options.label: C
options.text: That people tend to think that the bulk of their personal change is behind them

options.label: D
options.text: That people tend to overinvest in future choices based on past preferences

multiple-choice.question: According to the researchers, what is the primary consequence of the "End of History Illusion"?

options.label: A
options.text: We tend to overestimate our capacity for change

options.label: B
options.text: We tend to underestimate our capacity for change

options.label: C
options.text: We tend to overinvest in future choices based on present preferences

options.label: D
options.text: We tend to make more informed decisions about our future

multiple-choice.question: What was the method used by the researchers to study the "End of History Illusion"?

options.label: A
options.text: They asked participants to report their current personality traits and predict what they would be in ten years

options.label: B
options.text: They asked participants to report their current personality traits and what they had been ten years before

options.label: C
options.text: They asked half of the participants to report their current personality traits and what they had been ten years before, and the other half to describe their present selves and predict what they would be in ten years

options.label: D
options.text: They asked participants to report their current personality traits and compare them to their parents' traits

multiple-choice.question: What is the name of the political scientist whose prediction inspired the title "The End of History Illusion"?

According to the study, what is the average amount that people are willing to pay to see their current favorite musician ten years in the future compared to their favorite musician from ten years ago?
What is the age range of the participants in the study?
According to the study, which age group tends to change less than younger people?
What is the main idea behind the comparison of the predicted changes to the reported changes in the study?

options.label: A
options.text: To show that people tend to overestimate their ability to predict future change

options.label: B
options.text: To show that people tend to underestimate their ability to predict future change

options.label: C
options.text: To show that people tend to think that the bulk of their personal change is behind them

options.label: D
options.text: To show that people tend to make more informed decisions about their future

multiple-choice.question: What is the consequence of not having the "End of History Illusion"?

options.label: A
options.text: We would make more informed decisions about our future

options.label: B
options.text: We would tend to overinvest in future choices based on present preferences

options.label: C
options.text: We would be more open to new experiences

options.label: D
options.text: It would be difficult to make any long-term plans

multiple-choice.question: What is the main idea behind the application of the "End of History Illusion" to the wider world?

options.label: A
options.text: That we should assume that how things are now is how they will continue to be

options.label: B
options.text: That we should be aware that the world does change and that our current moment is not the end of history

options.label: C
options.text: That we should overinvest in future choices based on present preferences

options.label: D
options.text: That we should make more informed decisions about our future

title: Why should you read Edgar Allan Poe? - Scott Peeples

multiple-choice.question: What is one of the key features that makes Edgar Allan Poe's image instantly recognizable?

options.label: B
options.text: His disheveled black hair and sunken eyes

multiple-choice.question: According to Poe, what are the two cardinal rules for the short story form?

options.label: A
options.text: It must be long and every word must contribute to its purpose

options.label: B
options.text: It must be short enough to read in one sitting and every word must contribute to its purpose

options.label: C
options.text: It must be written in first person and every word must contribute to its purpose

options.label: D
options.text: It must be written in third person and every word must contribute to its purpose

multiple-choice.question: What effect does Poe aim to achieve through his stories, which goes beyond fear?
In "The Tell-Tale Heart," what is juxtaposed with the killer's violent act?

options.label: B
options.text: The killer's tender empathy towards the victim

multiple-choice.question: What literary device did Poe pioneer in his stories?
What genre of story did Poe invent with "The Murders in the Rue Morgue"?
What is the name of the detective in Poe's stories, who uses his genius and powers of observation to solve crimes?
What is the theme of many of Poe's poems, including "The Raven"?
What was a major struggle in Poe's personal life?

options.label: A
options.text: Poverty and loss of loved ones

multiple-choice.question: When did much of Poe's fame come, in relation to his lifetime?

options.label: C
options.text: Posthumously, through loose adaptations of his work

title: What would happen if every human suddenly disappeared? - Dan Kwartler

multiple-choice.question: What is the expected outcome for oil refineries in the event of human disappearance?

options.label: A
options.text: They will continue to function normally.

options.label: C
options.text: They will malfunction and produce month-long blazes.

options.label: D
options.text: They will be destroyed by natural disasters.

multiple-choice.question: What happens to underground rail systems like those in London, Moscow, and New York City after human disappearance?

options.label: B
options.text: They are abandoned but remain intact.

options.label: C
options.text: Hundreds of drainage pumps are abandoned, flooding the tunnels in just three days.

multiple-choice.question: What is the expected outcome for skyscrapers in cities built in river deltas like Houston after human disappearance?

options.label: B
options.text: They will collapse but remain intact.

options.label: C
options.text: They will eventually wash away completely, filling nearby tributaries with crushed concrete.

options.label: D
options.text: They will be destroyed by hurricanes.

multiple-choice.question: What happens to the biodiversity in a post-human world?

options.label: C
options.text: It increases, with new plant life and animal species thriving.

multiple-choice.question: Which of the following animals is likely to thrive in a post-human world?

options.label: C
options.text: Resourceful pigs, dogs, and feral housecats

multiple-choice.question: What is the expected outcome for the Earth's climate after human disappearance?

options.label: C
options.text: It will slowly recover from millennia of human impact.

multiple-choice.question: How long is it expected to take for the plant cycle to remove the last traces of lead left by the Industrial Revolution from Earth's soil?
What is the expected lifespan of America's Mt. Rushmore after human disappearance?
What happens to the remnants of cities built on floodplains after human disappearance?

options.label: A
options.text: They are destroyed by natural disasters.

options.label: B
options.text: They are preserved in time as a kind of technofossil.

options.label: C
options.text: They are abandoned but remain intact.

options.label: D
options.text: They are wiped from the planet's surface immediately.

multiple-choice.question: What can be learned by investigating the world without humans?

options.label: C
options.text: More about the world we live in now

title: How do cigarettes affect the body? - Krishna Sudhir

multiple-choice.question: What is the approximate number of chemical substances in cigarette smoke?

options.label: A

options.text: It displaces oxygen in the blood, leading to oxygen deprivation

options.label: B

options.label: A

options.label: B

options.label: C
options.text: The chances of developing fatal lung cancer decrease by 50%

options.label: D
options.text: The risk of coronary heart disease remains the same

options.label: B

options.label: C
options.text: To increase oxygen levels in the blood

multiple-choice.question: What is the long-term benefit of quitting smoking for 15 years?

options.label: A
options.text: The risk of heart disease decreases by 50%

options.label: B
options.text: The risk of stroke increases by 50%

options.label: C

title: How exactly does binary code work? - José Américo N L F Freitas

multiple-choice.question: What is the primary reason computers use binary code?

options.label: A
options.text: It's a fast way of storing data.

options.label: B
options.text: It's a reliable way of storing data.

options.label: C
options.text: It's a complex way of storing data.

options.label: D
options.text: It's an outdated way of storing data.

multiple-choice.question: How do transistors in a computer's main memory work?

options.label: A
options.text: They switch between high, low, and medium voltage levels.

options.label: B
options.text: They switch between high and low voltage levels, such as 5 volts and 0 volts.

options.label: C
options.text: They switch between high and low voltage levels, such as 10 volts and 0 volts.

options.label: D
options.text: They switch between low and medium voltage levels, such as 0 volts and 2.5 volts.

multiple-choice.question: How is the value of a binary sequence determined?

options.label: A
options.text: By its position in the sequence.

options.label: B
options.text: By a separate set of rules for each type of data.

options.label: C
options.text: By the number of 1s and 0s in the sequence.

options.label: D
options.text: By the length of the sequence.

options.text: Using the same decimal notation, but with base 2 instead of base 10.

options.label: B
options.text: Using a completely different notation that doesn't involve powers of 2.

options.label: C
options.text: Using a notation that involves powers of 2, similar to decimal notation with powers of 10.

options.label: D
options.text: Using a notation that involves powers of 8.

options.label: C

options.label: D

options.label: A
options.text: By looking at the sequence alone.

options.label: B
options.text: By using a special algorithm to analyze the sequence.

options.label: C
options.text: By considering the context in which the sequence is used.

options.label: D
options.text: By consulting a dictionary of binary sequences.

options.label: B
options.text: Each pixel is represented by three binary sequences that correspond to the primary colors.

options.label: C
options.text: Each pixel is represented by four binary sequences that correspond to the primary colors and black.

options.label: D
options.text: Each pixel is represented by a single binary sequence that corresponds to the secondary colors.

multiple-choice.question: What technique is used to store sound waves in binary?

options.label: A
options.text: To compress binary data by representing repeated values as a single value and a count.

options.label: B
options.text: To compress binary data by representing repeated values as separate values.

options.label: C
options.text: To compress binary data by eliminating repeated values.

options.label: D
options.text: To compress binary data by adding redundant values.

options.text: They are too complex to program.

options.label: C
options.text: They have not provided as much physical stability for data storage and transmission.

options.label: D
options.text: They are too slow to process data.

multiple-choice.question: What is one theory on why certain emotional expressions are universal?

According to Paul Ekman, what are the six core emotional expressions?

options.label: A
options.text: Anger, fear, surprise, sadness, happiness, and love

options.label: B
options.text: Anger, fear, surprise, sadness, happiness, and disgust

options.label: C
options.text: Anger, fear, surprise, sadness, happiness, and contempt

options.label: D
options.text: Anger, fear, surprise, sadness, happiness, and shame

multiple-choice.question: What is one way in which the fear expression could directly improve survival in potentially dangerous situations?

options.label: A
options.text: By letting our eyes absorb more light

options.label: B
options.text: By letting our lungs take in less air

multiple-choice.question: According to research, what do humans and some other primates pay more attention to when we're already on high alert?
What is one way in which emotional expressions could help improve group fitness?

options.label: A
options.text: By communicating our internal states to those around us

options.label: B
options.text: By hiding our internal states from those around us

options.label: C
options.text: By increasing conflict within the group

options.label: D
options.text: By decreasing cooperation within the group

title: How do your hormones work? - Emma Bryce

multiple-choice.question: What is the primary function of the endocrine system in the human body?

options.label: A
options.text: To control our behavior and emotions

options.label: B
options.text: To regulate our bodily processes and maintain balance

options.label: C
options.text: To produce hormones exclusively for growth and development

options.label: D
options.text: To manage only the reproductive system

multiple-choice.question: How many hormone-producing glands are present in the brain and the rest of the body, respectively?

options.label: A
options.text: 5 in the brain, 5 in the rest of the body

options.label: B
options.text: 3 in the brain, 7 in the rest of the body

options.label: C
options.text: 2 in the brain, 10 in the rest of the body

options.label: D
options.text: 7 in the brain, 3 in the rest of the body

multiple-choice.question: What is the role of receptors in the endocrine system?

options.label: B
options.text: To transport hormones through the bloodstream

options.label: C
options.text: To recognize and bind to specific hormones, triggering effects in the cell

multiple-choice.question: Which two hormones produced by the thyroid gland influence how quickly cells use energy and work?
What is the primary effect of testosterone during puberty in men?

options.label: A
options.text: To develop the ovaries and prepare the body for menstruation

options.label: B
options.text: To trigger the gradual development of the sexual organs, facial hair, and deepening of the voice

options.label: C
options.text: To regulate body temperature and digestion

options.label: D
options.text: To increase the production of serotonin

multiple-choice.question: What is a common misconception about the endocrine system?

options.label: A
options.text: That hormones have unlimited power over our behavior

options.label: B
options.text: That the endocrine system only regulates growth and development

options.label: C
options.text: That there are exclusively male and female hormones

options.label: D
options.text: That the thyroid gland only produces one hormone

multiple-choice.question: How do hormones influence mood changes?

options.label: B
options.text: By influencing the production of certain chemicals in the brain, such as serotonin

options.label: C
options.text: By regulating body temperature and digestion

multiple-choice.question: What is the primary cause of diabetes, a common hormonal disorder?

options.label: A
options.text: The pancreas secretes too much insulin

options.label: B
options.text: The pancreas secretes too little insulin

options.label: C
options.text: The thyroid gland produces too much thyroid hormone

options.label: D
options.text: The adrenal gland produces too little adrenaline

multiple-choice.question: What is the effect of too little thyroid hormone in the body?

options.label: B
options.text: Slowed heart rate, fatigue, and depression

options.label: C
options.text: Increased heart rate, energy, and happiness

options.label: D
options.text: No significant effects on the body

multiple-choice.question: What is the overall effect of the endocrine system's constant regulation in the body?

options.label: A
options.text: To disrupt bodily processes and cause disease

options.label: B
options.text: To control our behavior and emotions

options.label: C
options.text: To drive changes that ultimately help us become who we are

options.label: D
options.text: To only regulate growth and development

title: 3 rules to spark learning - Ramsey Musallam

multiple-choice.question: What is the speaker's profession?
According to the speaker, what is the most important aspect of learning?
What life-threatening situation did the speaker face that changed his approach to teaching?
What are the three rules that the speaker follows in his lesson planning?

options.label: A
options.text: Curiosity comes first, Embrace the mess, and Practice reflection

options.label: B
options.text: Technology is key, Scripted curriculum is essential, and Instructional time is crucial

options.label: C
options.text: Student questions are irrelevant, Trial and error is a waste of time, and Reflection is unnecessary

multiple-choice.question: What is the speaker's opinion on flipping a boring lecture from the classroom to the screen of a mobile device?

options.label: A
options.text: It is an effective way to engage students

options.label: B
options.text: It saves instructional time but can be dehumanizing

options.label: C
options.text: It is a waste of time and resources

options.label: D
options.text: It is only suitable for certain subjects

multiple-choice.question: According to the speaker, what is the role of teachers in the 21st century?
What is the speaker's view on trial and error in the learning process?

options.label: A
options.text: It is a necessary part of learning

options.label: B
options.text: It is a waste of time and resources

options.label: C
options.text: It is only suitable for certain subjects

options.label: D
options.text: It is irrelevant in the 21st century

multiple-choice.question: How does the speaker think teachers can bring more meaning to their students' school day?

options.label: B
options.text: By embracing a new paradigm as cultivators of curiosity and inquiry

options.label: C
options.text: By sticking to traditional teaching methods

multiple-choice.question: What is the speaker's opinion on student curiosity?

options.label: A
options.text: It is a hindrance to learning

options.label: B
options.text: It is a necessary part of learning

options.label: C
options.text: It is only relevant in certain subjects

options.label: D
options.text: It is irrelevant in the 21st century

multiple-choice.question: What is the speaker's message to teachers regarding their students?

options.label: A
options.text: Students are not worth the effort

options.label: B
options.text: Students are worth the effort, and teachers should strive to be the surgeons of their classrooms

options.label: C
options.text: Students are only worth the effort if they are high-achieving

options.label: D
options.text: Students are not the responsibility of teachers

title: How one scientist averted a national health crisis - Andrea Tone

multiple-choice.question: In what year did Frances Oldham Kelsey join the Food and Drug Administration (FDA)?
What was the name of the US drug company that applied to sell thalidomide in the US?
What was the primary concern that led Kelsey to reject Merrell's application for thalidomide?

options.label: A
options.text: Inadequate data on absorption and toxicity

options.label: B
options.text: Lack of testing on pregnant animals

options.label: C
options.text: Insufficient evidence of the drug's effectiveness

multiple-choice.question: What was the common belief among experts in 1960 regarding the placental barrier?

options.label: A
options.text: It allowed drugs to pass from mother to fetus

options.label: B
options.text: It shielded the fetus from harm

options.label: C
options.text: It had no effect on the fetus

multiple-choice.question: What was the outcome of thalidomide use by pregnant women?

options.label: B
options.text: It had no effect on the fetus

options.label: C
options.text: It reduced the risk of morning sickness

options.label: D
options.text: It increased the risk of miscarriage

multiple-choice.question: How many applications did Merrell submit for thalidomide before withdrawing their final application?
What was the result of Kelsey's actions regarding thalidomide?

options.label: A
options.text: The drug was approved for use in the US

options.label: B
options.text: The drug was pulled from the German market

options.label: C
options.text: The drug was kept off the US market

multiple-choice.question: What was the impact of the thalidomide scare on the FDA's authority?
What was Kelsey's role in the FDA after the thalidomide scare?

options.label: C
options.text: She headed the agency's drug investigation branch

options.label: D
options.text: She remained in the same position

multiple-choice.question: What was the legacy of Frances Oldham Kelsey's actions regarding thalidomide?

options.label: B
options.text: She took shortcuts in the review process

options.label: C
options.text: She made evidence-based medicine the foundation of reforms

title: What would it be like to live on the moon? - Alex Gendler

multiple-choice.question: What is the European Space Agency's goal regarding the establishment of a "moon camp"?

options.label: A
options.text: To establish a functioning moon camp by the 2050s

options.label: B
options.text: To establish a functioning moon camp by the 2020s

options.label: C
options.text: To establish a functioning moon camp by the 2070s

options.label: D
options.text: To establish a functioning moon camp by the 2100s

multiple-choice.question: What is the biggest obstacle to living on the moon?
How much more radiation can a person on the moon's surface receive compared to the maximum safe dosage?
What would be used to construct covered habitats from lunar soil?
Why is it necessary for lunar inhabitants to exercise for hours a day?

options.label: A
options.text: To maintain bone and muscle mass due to the moon's low gravity

options.label: B
options.text: To maintain bone and muscle mass due to the moon's high gravity

multiple-choice.question: What is one potential benefit of having a radio telescope on the far side of the moon?

options.label: A
options.text: It could observe the Earth's electromagnetic interference

options.label: B
options.text: It could observe the cosmos, shielded from the Earth's electromagnetic interference

options.label: C
options.text: It could observe the sun's electromagnetic interference

options.label: D
options.text: It could observe the moon's electromagnetic interference

multiple-choice.question: What is one potential economic benefit of the moon?

options.label: A
options.text: It is rich in minerals like silicon, aluminum, and magnesium

options.label: B
options.text: It is rich in minerals like gold, silver, and copper

options.label: C
options.text: It is rich in minerals like iron, titanium, and chromium

options.label: D
options.text: It is rich in minerals like uranium, thorium, and plutonium

multiple-choice.question: What is the potential role of the moon base in future space operations?

options.label: A
options.text: A testing ground, refueling station, and supply depot

options.label: B
options.text: A testing ground and refueling station

options.label: C
options.text: A testing ground and supply depot

options.label: D
options.text: A refueling station and supply depot

multiple-choice.question: Which of the following is NOT a potential participant in the moon camp project?
What is the potential long-term benefit of the moon camp?

options.label: A
options.text: It would be a stepping stone for missions to the International Space Station

options.label: B
options.text: It would be a stepping stone for missions to the sun

options.label: C
options.text: It would be a stepping stone for missions to other planets and becoming an interplanetary species

options.label: D
options.text: It would be a stepping stone for missions to the asteroid belt

title: Can you solve the penniless pilgrim riddle? - Dan Finkel

multiple-choice.question: What is the initial amount of tax owed after passing through the gate and the welcome center?
What happens to the tax when you walk east?
What is the effect of walking one clockwise loop around a single block on the tax owed?
What is the effect of walking one counterclockwise loop around a single block on the tax owed?
How many counterclockwise loops would be needed to reduce the initial tax owed to 0 silver?
Why can't the pilgrim simply walk four counterclockwise loops to reduce the tax owed to 0 silver?

options.label: B
options.text: It would require walking the same block twice

options.label: C
options.text: It would not be a direct route

options.label: D
options.text: It would not be a valid solution

multiple-choice.question: What is the amount of tax owed after walking three blocks south and two blocks east?
What is the effect of walking three blocks north and one block west on the tax owed?

options.label: D
options.text: It decreases by 2.5 silver is the result of the decrease, not the amount decreased

multiple-choice.question: What is the amount of tax owed after walking the remaining three blocks west and one block south?
What is the final amount of tax owed after walking the three blocks to the south wall?

title: Why is it so hard to cure ALS? - Fernando Vieira

multiple-choice.question: What is the name of the rare neuromuscular disorder that Stephen Hawking was diagnosed with in 1963?
What percentage of ALS cases are hereditary?
What is the typical age range for the first appearance of ALS symptoms?
What is the average life expectancy of people with ALS after diagnosis?
What is the primary function of upper motor neurons in the neuromuscular system?

options.label: A
options.text: To transmit messages from the brain to lower motor neurons

options.label: B
options.text: To transmit messages from lower motor neurons to muscle fibers

options.label: C
options.text: To contract or relax muscle fibers

multiple-choice.question: What happens to the muscles when motor neurons degenerate in ALS?
What is one of the prevailing ideas about the cause of ALS?

options.label: C
options.text: Misfolded proteins forming clumps inside motor neurons

multiple-choice.question: What is a potential consequence of defective immune cells in ALS patients?

options.label: A
options.text: Inflammation in the brain and spinal cord

multiple-choice.question: What type of therapies are being developed to repair damaged cells in ALS patients?
What is the ultimate goal of ongoing research and discoveries in ALS?

options.label: A
options.text: To understand the causes of ALS

options.label: B
options.text: To develop new treatments for ALS

options.label: C
options.text: To change the future for people living with ALS

title: The journey to Pluto, the farthest world ever explored - Alan Stern

multiple-choice.question: What was the primary objective of the New Horizons spacecraft?

options.label: A
options.text: To explore Jupiter and its moons

options.label: B
options.text: To explore Pluto, collect scientific data, and transmit it back to Earth

options.label: D
options.text: To search for life on Mars

multiple-choice.question: Why did astronomers want to explore Pluto before 2020?

options.label: A
options.text: Because Pluto's atmosphere would become too dense to study

options.label: B
options.text: Because Pluto's atmosphere could freeze, and its surface would be shrouded in darkness

options.label: C
options.text: Because Pluto would be too far away from Earth to study

options.label: D
options.text: Because Pluto's orbit would take it too close to the Sun

multiple-choice.question: What is the name of the region in our solar system where Pluto is located?
What type of assist did New Horizons receive from Jupiter to increase its speed?
Why was New Horizons on a flyby mission to Pluto?

options.label: A
options.text: Because it was too expensive to land on Pluto

options.label: B
options.text: Because it was too difficult to orbit Pluto

options.label: C
options.text: Because New Horizons was traveling too fast to slow down and orbit or land on Pluto

options.label: D
options.text: Because Pluto's atmosphere was too dense to land on

options.label: A
options.text: It successfully transmitted data back to Earth

options.label: B
options.text: It experienced a malfunction and lost contact with Earth

options.label: C
options.text: It encountered a solar flare that damaged its instruments

options.label: D
options.text: It ran out of fuel and had to be shut down

multiple-choice.question: Who led the team that reloaded the instructions into New Horizons after it malfunctioned?
What is the name of the 1000-kilometer-wide glacier discovered on Pluto?
What is the composition of Sputnik Planitia?

options.label: C
options.text: Mainly composed of rock and dust

multiple-choice.question: What is the next destination for the New Horizons spacecraft after Pluto?

title: Why do we sweat? - John Murnan

multiple-choice.question: What is the primary purpose of sweat in the human body?
What process consumes glucose and oxygen to form ATP, the energy currency of the cell?
Where does the process of cellular respiration primarily take place?
What stimulates temperature sensors throughout the body to detect excess heat?
Which part of the brain regulates body temperature and responds to temperature sensors?
What is the process by which water moves into the tube of the sweat gland due to a concentration gradient?
What is the term for the cooling effect that occurs when sweat evaporates off the skin?
Why do people sweat when they eat spicy food?

options.label: A
options.text: Because spices trigger the same neural response as increased heat

options.label: B
options.text: Because spices stimulate the release of adrenaline

multiple-choice.question: Why do people sweat when they are sick with a fever?

options.label: A
options.text: Because the infection stimulates the hypothalamus to increase muscle activity

options.label: B
options.text: Because the infection stimulates the release of adrenaline

options.label: C
options.text: Because the infection increases blood pressure

options.label: D
options.text: Because the infection decreases heart rate

multiple-choice.question: What is the result of the hypothalamus sensing a decrease in heat after a fever or intense exercise?

options.label: D
options.text: The sweating response is brought to an end

title: How does hibernation work? - Sheena Faherty

multiple-choice.question: What is the primary reason for hibernation in animals?

options.label: B
options.text: To survive the harsh winter months

multiple-choice.question: Which of the following animals is known to multitask during hibernation?
What happens to an animal's heartbeat during hibernation?

options.label: A
options.text: It increases to maintain body temperature

options.label: B
options.text: It remains the same as normal

options.label: C
options.text: It slows down to about 1 to 3% of its original speed

multiple-choice.question: What is the term for the regular bouts of reduced metabolic rate and body temperature during hibernation?
Why do researchers study the genomes of hibernating animals?

options.label: A
options.text: To understand their behavior and physiology

options.label: B
options.text: To develop new treatments for diseases

options.label: C
options.text: To improve our understanding of human hibernation

multiple-choice.question: What is the potential benefit of studying how hibernating animals control their weight?

options.label: A
options.text: Understanding the relationship between metabolism and weight gain in humans

options.label: C
options.text: Improving our understanding of human physiology

options.label: D
options.text: Understanding the behavior of hibernating animals

multiple-choice.question: Which of the following is a potential application of understanding how hibernators deal with reduced blood flow?

options.label: B
options.text: Protecting the brain during a stroke

options.label: C
options.text: Improving our understanding of human physiology

options.label: D
options.text: Understanding the behavior of hibernating animals

multiple-choice.question: What happens to an animal's brain activity during hibernation?

options.label: A
options.text: It increases to maintain body temperature

options.label: B
options.text: It remains the same as normal

multiple-choice.question: How do hibernating animals stay alive during the hibernation period?

options.label: A
options.text: By having just enough blood and oxygen moving around their bodies

multiple-choice.question: What is the potential long-term goal of researching hibernation in animals?

options.label: A
options.text: To develop new treatments for diseases

options.label: B
options.text: To improve our understanding of human physiology

options.label: C
options.text: To make human hibernation a real possibility

title: How do we study living brains? - John Borghi and Elizabeth Waters

multiple-choice.question: What is the primary challenge in studying the human brain?

options.label: B
options.text: Its complex structure and protective layers

multiple-choice.question: Which technique measures electrical activity in the brain?
What is a limitation of EEG in studying brain activity?

options.label: B
options.text: It cannot measure changes that occur in milliseconds

options.label: C
options.text: It is hard to determine exactly where any particular pattern originates

options.label: D
options.text: It can only diagnose sleep disorders

multiple-choice.question: What does fMRI measure in the brain?
How does fMRI help in studying brain activity?

options.label: A
options.text: It provides information about the timing of neural activity

options.label: B
options.text: It pinpoints differences in brain activity to within a few millimeters

options.label: C
options.text: It measures the complex chemistry in the brain

multiple-choice.question: What is the purpose of introducing radioactive elements into the brain during a PET scan?

options.label: A
options.text: To study the brain's electrical activity

options.label: C
options.text: To study the complex chemistry in the brain

multiple-choice.question: What is a limitation of PET scans in studying brain activity?

options.label: C
options.text: They cannot measure changes that occur in milliseconds

options.label: D
options.text: They can only detect diseases like Alzheimer's

multiple-choice.question: How do EEG, fMRI, and PET scans collectively help doctors and scientists?

options.label: A
options.text: They provide a complete understanding of brain activity

options.label: B
options.text: They connect what happens in the brain with our behavior

options.label: D
options.text: They study the complex chemistry in the brain

multiple-choice.question: What is a potential future development in brain imaging technology?

options.label: A
options.text: More accurate results from current techniques

options.label: B
options.text: The ability to distinguish the activity of individual neurons

options.label: C
options.text: A new technique that replaces EEG, fMRI, and PET scans

options.label: D
options.text: A way to study the brain without any imaging techniques

multiple-choice.question: What is the ultimate goal of studying the human brain?

options.label: C
options.text: To understand one of the most remarkable things we've ever encountered
